awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Cultural Contestations and Genetically Modified Crops In a Non-Western Context
awd_abstract_narration:
SES- 1602495
Jill Harrison
Jessie K. Luna
University of Colorado at Boulder

This dissertation research will add to our understanding of the polarized debates over the role of genetically engineered crops in development.  This project seeks to understand the social and cultural dimensions of peoples' practices and understandings of genetically engineered crops. In doing so, it will shed light on the reasons why some actors have embraced or benefited from biotech crops, whereas others have not, and why there are differences in how things play out "on the ground" as opposed to "in theory."  The study examines the role of social and cultural practices in the adoption (and sometimes rejection) of genetically engineered cotton in the West African country of Burkina Faso, one of the only African countries currently growing genetically engineered crop.  Research findings will help contribute to regional policy regarding agricultural development.

This research builds on academic literatures that studies the privatization of nature - including seeds. It asks how the logics associated with genetically modified seeds intersect with non-Western and non-neoliberal logics. Using tools from Science and Technology Studies, the research will ask how the logics of neoliberal nature "travel" and encounter cultural friction and transformation. The co-PI will collect qualitative data from interviews and participant observation with researchers, civil society actors, cotton extension agents, cotton farmers of different class positions, and rural women. The research will use iterative and comparative analysis to identify zones of transformation, conflict, or resistance.  The researcher will examine cultural narratives and identity claims, as well as peoples' changing interactions with ecological landscapes. These findings will ultimately shed light on how processes of capitalist expansion both shape and are shaped by non-economic and non-Western logics.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF DDRI funding supported eight months of ethnographic fieldwork in Burkina Faso, West Africa. This research sought to understand the cultural components of how and why Burkinabe farmers are using and adopting new agricultural technologies, including genetically modified seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, and tractors. This question was motivated by a gap in both academic literature and public debate regarding the role of new technologies in African agricultural change. In particular, there has been very little research that examines how culture and identity shape the use and outcomes of new agricultural technologies.

My research traced how new agricultural technologies are understood and used at different “levels” of the cotton sector, ranging from research scientists and managers all the way to rural farmers (men and women). With the help of DDRI funding, I hired two masters-level Burkinabe research assistants who helped me navigate entry to a wide range of sites, where we conducted extensive ethnographic fieldwork. Over the course of eight months, I conducted 125 interviews in French and the local language Dioula, one month of participant observation with the state cotton company, and five months of participant observation in a small farming town. I sought to understand the broader context of social change and systems of social meaning that shape farmers’ choices and behaviors. Additionally, I spent several weeks observing and interviewing organic cotton farmers to understand how and why some farmers opt for an alternative production system.

My findings reveal novel insights about agricultural change and technology adoption that contribute to furthering academic knowledge as well as making a broader impact for socially desired outcomes. In terms of furthering knowledge, my research explicitly draws together literature on agrarian change with broader theories on racialized modernity and environmental justice. I found that many actors in Burkina Faso are enthusiastic about purchased agricultural technologies (including genetically modified seeds, pesticides, fertilizers, and tractors). I show how a combination of reinforcing political-economic and cultural forces compels Burkinabè farmers to embrace these technologies.

First, the global economic system constrains farmer choice, leaving farmers few options other than to try to increase their production of poorly remunerated cash crops. Yet farmers also take part in the distinction politics of Burkina Faso’s postcolonial cultural field, seeking to acquire the symbolic and material status of Western, “white” modernity. As people seek to maintain or improve their own status, they justify passing on exploitation and pressure to increase production to other actors, they embrace “modern” technologies, and their families become increasingly individualized and thus reliant on technology rather than family labor. The novel contribution of this dissertation is to argue that aspirations for status within a racialized and unequal global culture have facilitated the expansion of capitalist agriculture in Burkina Faso, and thus – ironically – the deepening of both environmental and economic inequalities (high levels of debt and increasing exposure to toxic chemicals).

In addition to contributing to academic knowledge, my findings have the potential to make broader contributions to society. First, they inform agricultural development efforts in Africa. They reveal that many mainstream development efforts, which frame new technologies as helping “save” African farmers from poverty, overlook rising global and local inequalities and issues of farmer exposure to pesticides. However, my findings also suggest that current alternatives, such as certified organic agriculture, overlook farmers’ desires for modernity and increasing labor shortages. My findings point to the need for “middle path," participatory, and sustainable agricultural development approaches that recognize a role for technologies, yet help to sustain livelihoods for even the poorest rural residents. Finally, my findings contribute to recent literature that reveals the deeply racialized dimensions of contemporary global economic and cultural hierarchies. Efforts to address these global inequalities (i.e. through development projects) must do a better job of directly confronting these questions of race and racism.
